text: His TINY HANDS come into frame. Scavenging. IN TIGHTER: the same hands. Clearly a practised routine. A YELLOW BUTTERFLY flutters onto the hand. The hand STILL so as not to scare the butterfly. Our tiny figure (SAROO, 5) stands up, ever so carefully. FRONT ANGLE: we see him properly for the first time. Stud the butterfly. Entranced. Then he notices a few more. WIDER: he’s in a field entirely filled with their flutter Delighted, he spreads his arms wide. He moves through the butterflies - fluttering all around his head and shoulder Suddenly - a 5-year-old testing his powers - he ROARS -
- laughing - the butterflies scatter all around him -
Saroo! Saroo! In the distance, up on the railway line that runs along t ridge, a silhouette. Saroo’s BROTHER (GUDDU, 12) waves.

Saroo and Guddu hide in wait in the shrubs along the trac A huge COAL TRAIN lumbers toward them, picking up speed. Guddu bursts out - clambers up onto the moving train. Saroo runs alongside, terrified and at the same time lovi the thrill. His bare feet hurting on the rough ground. Guddu effortlessly swings himself onto the open coal car.

Keep up! Keep up! Guddu starts throwing coal off the train, into the makesh net of Saroo’s shirt - mostly missing. At any moment Saroo could go under those giant wheels. Along the tracks: THREE MEN (SECURITY) give chase, shouti Guddu clambers down. The boys scramble for stray lumps of coal. But they don’t have much time; the men are gaining. They peel off into the dense scrub, giggling as they spri well-trodden short-cuts; the men begin to recede, B/G.
Bustling Khandwa. Colors, street stalls, people everywher Saroo and Guddu stride confidently through all this, hold their pregnant coal bellies in place. They know this rout

They dump the coal into a STREET VENDOR’s bucket. As the vendor ladles out a small plastic bag of warm milk from a bubbling vat, Saroo notices something to his side POV, as in a dream: in another vat, rich, deep-orange Jal sizzle - an unattainable feast that makes Saroo salivate.
(nudges Guddu) Guddu ... Jalebis ... Guddu looks at them too; for a beat we see beyond the boy deep hunger - they’re just kids, yearning for a sweet.

They run along the road home. Joyful, free. A job well do Turning into the final alley, they pass a house with a l aqua wall, and a hedge of overflowing bougainvillea. All the while we keep our eye on that little plastic bag.

Home is a dirt-floor shack. Kerosene lamp. Bare walls. Co fire in the corner. Plastic dish tub. Subsistence living. Saroo’s MOTHER (KAMLA, 30 - beautiful, but lined by life) ladles dhal onto plates for Saroo, Guddu, and SHEKILA (2) KALLU (a boy, 9 - Saroo and Guddu’s brother, cheeky, flig enters, sits, unwrapping a cloth containing scraps of bre
I got the bread!

(it’s competitive) We got the milk! They devour the meal in silence. We study each person. Kamla unties the plastic bag, pours the milk into a bowl. dips a crust of bread and gives it to Shekila to suckle o Guddu, Kallu, and Saroo take a sip each and pass the bowl Saroo offers the bowl to his mother. She smiles a gentle Saroo grins at Guddu. So proud of their milk escapade. Kallu ups and leaves as fast as he came.
Saroo lies with Shekila on her little “cot” - barely a sc of mattress - on the floor. Soothing her, stroking her he
Shhh. Shhh. Saroo lifts his head, looks at Kamla as she drapes her he with a silk sari and begins to head out. She looks back at his questioning little face.
You know I have to work.
Stillness of the night outside. Shekila sleeps; Saroo nea there. But when Guddu slips out the door, Saroo sees him
Guddu wrestles his rickety bicycle from its hiding place.
How long this time? Guddu turns to see Saroo standing there.
You did good today, Saroo.
I want to come with you. How long?
A week. You have to mind Shekila.
Kallu will be back.
You're too little to carry sacks. It’s very hard work.
I can carry anything! Guddu smiles, amused. Really? With great effort, Saroo lifts up the bicycle, holds it a above his head, like a weight-lifter. Straining.
Okay. Put it down. Guddu laughs at the absurdity and sheer balls.
Travelling at breakneck speed - Saroo joyfully perched on handlebars - the boys emerge from the underpass. The busy streets whizzing past. Guddu the daredevil.
Go, Guddu! On Saroo: so proud of his big brother. This is living!
Saroo and Guddu standing on a crowded night train. Hemmed

The majority of the crowd are disembarking at a station.  In a deftly-practised move, Saroo and Guddu scurry like monkeys under the seats, scavenging for scraps. On Guddu: he finds a peso. (It’s about 1/100th of a Rupee
Peso! On Saroo: he grabs something. A peanut. He cracks the she
Guddu! He splits the single peanut in two, and they eat it.
The train is moving again. Plenty of seats now. Saroo looks totally exhausted, his head resting on Guddu. Guddu strokes Saroo, dreamily staring out into the blackn
The train pulls into Burhanpur Station. The PASSENGERS disembark. Last off is Guddu, carrying sleeping Saroo. Guddu sits Saroo down on a bench.
Saroo - wake up! Saroo simply groans, and curls up sideways.
You have to walk.
(whiny) I’m asleep ...
You're too little for late nights!
I’m asleep ... Don’t bother me. Guddu looks around. Annoyed with himself. Back to Saroo:
I'll go sort things for tomorrow. Then we can find a place to sleep.
Bring back a thousand jalebis.

Very funny. Wait here. You don’t move, okay? Guddu leaps off the end of the platform. Familiar with it ON Saroo: deep asleep in an instant. ON Guddu: tiny figure, hopping his way along the tracks. FADE TO BLACK.
FADE UP: Saroo wakes. The platform now all but deserted - empty, haunted. A few scattered, shadowy MEN in the dista Saroo looks around. Coming to consciousness. Where is Gud
Guddu? Those shadowy MEN in the distance, huddled, smoking. We feel Saroo’s total vulnerability to this weird open sp A big empty train, standing in front of him.

Guddu? He looks up at the giant WATER TOWER behind the platform. Looming, almost alive - like some brooding iron monster. What to do? Where on earth is Guddu? One of the shadowy m gives Saroo one of those stares that never break. A moment of decision. CLOSE on Saroo. And just like that - step! - Saroo steps up onto the trai
Little Saroo just stands there. The carriage is dark, emp

Guddu? He walks down the aisle to the end of the carriage. He tr the connecting door. It’s locked. He stands in the doorway, looking out. Still no Guddu. He retreats back inside. Safer here. He sits. Knees drawn. Taking in the measure of this new e space. His lids heavy. He lies there. Spooked, but fading He curls up. Fighting sleep so hard. Then his lids fall

Daylight. CLOSE on Saroo, eyelids flickering in sleep, he rocking gently, as a sunbeam creeps across his face. AUDIO: the distant, soothing clickety-clack of the train. POV: we’re in a sun-drenched, empty train carriage. (And suddenly that clickety-clack is pretty damn loud.) ON Saroo: as he lurches awake. His catastrophe has begun. As he stands up, taking in his surroundings, sheer terror - he’s like a feral animal, realizing it’s trapped. He slaps his hands to the window, looks out. Panicking, he jumps across the aisle. Looks out. He runs up the aisle. Tries the lock of the connecting do The main door: locked. Distraught, he looks out the windo POV (REVERSE): an endless expanse of ochre plains racing
(through the bars) Guddu! Ammi!* [*Mummy] Shekila! He sits back, mind racing. Frozen, mute.
The train hurtles across the land. [We note the rest of t train is crowded. Only the last carriage, Saroo’s, is emp

Time has passed. Saroo is staring numbly at the ceiling. The train lurches, slows. Saroo tenses. Jumps up, hopeful Out the window (POV): we’ve entered a mid-sized TOWN. The train comes to a stop at last. But where is the platf Saroo cranes his neck at the window bars once again. POV (REVERSE): oblique angle, partial view, we catch a GLIMPSE of the human activity on the platform further alo
WIDE EXTERIOR, we now see what’s actually going on: Saroo carriage, the last one, hangs over the end of the platfor Little Saroo, craning at the bars of a window.

Saroo is back at the carriage door, trying the handle, on toes trying to get a glimpse out the window. (His POV): just near him, legs dangling over the end of t platform, sits a single STREET URCHIN (10), black with gr Saroo bangs on the door window.
Help me!
From the urchin’s POV: Saroo, trapped behind the dirty pa

Help me! The urchin stares blankly at Saroo. In his own desolation can’t find the energy to even engage, let alone help. SAROO (CONT’D) Please! Help me! But the train begins to pull out. Gathering speed. The urchin turns his head, and gazes at Saroo, receding.
As the train continues to gather speed we see, over Saroo shoulder, all the people on the crowded platform flashing
(flailing, screaming) Help! Help! But not a soul notices him - and then the station is gone
The train continues across the vast landscape, whose colo have shifted now - less ochre, more verdant.
Saroo, just sitting. Weeping forlorn, hopeless tears.
NIGHT. Saroo on all fours under the seats again, scavengi He lunges for a peach stone. Well and truly eaten. He gna and sucks on it ravenously, getting at the last strands.

Saroo watches out the window a dark, unfamiliar CITY streaming past. A vast SHANTY TOWN at night. And such NOI The train begins to slow, noticeably. Saroo, pressed to t window, wide-eyed. Scared. But desperate to get off!

As the train lurches to a stop, Saroo is poised at the do tensed, wary, alert. PEOPLE crowd the door. To Saroo, they seem frightening, ugly: a Boschean nightma of faces, all crowding at the door. How’s this going to work? His hand tight on the handle. AUDIO: a HYDRAULIC AIR RELEASE SOUND, and the door unlock It slides OPEN, and instantly the CROWDS are PILING IN. Saroo, caught off-guard, pushes forward. THROWS himself i the crowd, like a stage diver. No way he isn’t getting of

The HORDES push on board as tiny Saroo fights his way out Desperate. Lunging. Swimming his way through them. He pops clear. Free. But then, before him: the chaos of Howrah, Calcutta’s main terminus - 26 platforms. WIDE, th place is indescribably vast. The size of a small town. He turns in a circle - every direction equally hopeless. He steps up to a WOMAN.
Ganestlay?
(waving him off) I have no money. To a MAN IN RAILWAY UNIFORM walking by:

Ganestlay?  10 But the man keeps walking. Saroo sees ANOTHER OFFICIAL. He tugs on the man’s trouser But the man just BATS Saroo away - a real clip on the ear Turning in a bewildered circle, Saroo spots a STREET KID drinking from a water fountain then walking off. Saroo steps up, tippy-toes, and drinks. And drinks. Two d without food or water. This is the Fountain of Life. Then his eyes search for that street kid.

Up the far end of the platform, the kid sits down with a bunch of STREET KIDS, all of them so blackened with grime CLOSER: some rowdy, some quiet. Some already asleep. ON SAROO: studying them. Cautiously approaching. He sits, twenty metres away, eyeing them warily. ON THE CHILDREN: a wild, dangerous energy. A WIRY BOY, 10, returns Saroo’s stare. No invitation here He’s not being accepted. Eyes at ten paces. LATER. Saroo sleeps - sitting up, knees drawn, head droop FADE TO BLACK. OVER THE BLACKNESS (PRE-LAP): a SHRIEKING STATION WHISTLE

Saroo, standing in front of a packed train about to leave the platform where he arrived yesterday. That WHISTLE blows again. The train lurches into movement Saroo’s mind ticking. Here it is. The chance to go home. At the last possible moment Saroo leaps on the moving tra
Saroo pushes inside, stands there holding the pole. Taking everyone in. He tugs on a LADY’s sari.

Ganestlay? The woman grunts - huh? - and looks away. Saroo pushes through. Asks a MAN.  11 SAROO (CONT’D) Ganestlay? Nothing. The man just looks away. On Saroo: the invisible boy. Looking up at all these ADUL
The train hurtles along, now through the night.

The train pulls into a TERMINUS, where EVERYONE alights. Saroo jumps up from under that seat. Instantly awake, he for the door. Excited. This should be Ganestlay. He stands in the doorway - lost, looking up the platform, carriage behind him now empty. This is not Ganestlay.
(re: the empty train) This one terminates here. Saroo doesn’t understand a word he says.
Ganestlay?
(gesturing) Go! Shoo!
(confused) Ganestlay? The guard points to the crowded train on the other platfo
Two minutes. Go! To Saroo, that’s a Yes to the Ganestlay question. As he sprints up the overpass to the train on the opposit platform, we feel his rush of hope.
Saroo jumps on, squeezes through the crush. So tiny. He perches himself at a window - on the edge of his seat looking out - ahead. Could this really be it? He catches a LADY looking at him.  12

(pleased with himself) Ganestlay. She smiles. Whatever he’s saying, the little kid is sweet He points out the window, as the train starts to move. SAROO (CONT’D) Ganestlay. The lady doesn’t understand. But perhaps she can be helpf
Calcutta.

(trying the word) Cal-cutta. It dents his optimism a little. He’s so easily confused. “Calcutta”. What the hell is she talking about? He notices a SCHOOL GIRL staring at him. His filthy cloth He’s already beginning to look like those street kids.

Saroo, leaning out the open doorway - calm, content. In h bones: soon home will reappear. CLOSER on Saroo as confusion sets in. Then a sinking feel WIDE (Saroo’s POV): we’re slowing, coming into ... Calcut The SHANTY TOWN again. Howrah ahead in the distance. Oh,
We FOLLOW forlorn Saroo as he walks through the CROWDS ac the Howrah Station CONCOURSE and goes up to a TICKET BOOT On tiptoes, his head barely appears at the window.

Ganestlay? The MAN shoos him away, as people are piling up behind hi SAROO (CONT’D) (more insistent) Ganestlay? The man is now impatient and shouts at Saroo; the PASSENG push and slap him out of the way.  13
Saroo, so tiny, as he walks along the VAST, CROWDED subwa passage (SINGLE SHOT, WIDE) - a subterranean nightmare.

CLOSE: Saroo stands bathed in the late afternoon light - gazing out at something. A gentle breeze on his face. He looks left. Looks right. Looks ahead. Then with a resi slump, he turns and walks off. WIDE: he’s walking back (towards the station) across an ENORMOUS COBWEB of entangled train tracks - an IMPENETRAB WEAVE that really shows just how impossible getting home

LATE; the lost children are curled up, entangled, asleep. Forlorn Saroo sits down - same wary distance as the other night. His eyes tired and red. His grimy face tear-staine He now looks just like them - the transformation is compl Eye contact with Wiry Boy, who’s lying on a bed of cardbo Wiry Boy shifts, nods to Saroo - slides out one of the la of cardboard that make up his bed. Slides it over to Saro Saroo - I can? An offer of extraordinary generosity. Saroo walks over, takes it, lies down. A luxury. Saroo nods Thank-you, smiles shyly. Wiry Boy nods solemnl As Saroo closes his eyes, we FADE TO BLACK. SILENCE.
- Saroo is woken by screaming and sudden pandemonium. SHADOWY ADULTS are grabbing at the children - it is terrifying and aggressive and chaotic -

Come here! Hey! You! - and the children are screaming in terror and scattering A STATION OFFICIAL casually lights a cigarette. (In his nonchalance, a sense of the machinery of corruption.)  14 Springing into survival mode, Saroo runs for his life - straight up the end of the platform, and leaps straight o

- and into the tunnel. The last thing he sees, as he turn for one last glance, is Wiry Boy being violently taken aw Saroo sprints along the tunnel. A MAN chases. ON Saroo: a heart-pounding chase. Rats scurrying everywhe

Hey! You come here! You come back! Suddenly, danger: a train hurtling towards him. Blinded, Saroo flattens himself against the wall, terrifi The train barely misses him, as it blares past. As Saroo stands there, pinned against the wall amid all t electrical cables, head turned sideways, he sees -— - along there, the body snatcher, also pressed to the wal Now the train is gone - and here comes the body snatcher - nowhere to go but forward - Saroo keeps sprinting - at the body snatcher gives up -

- Saroo emerges into the world outside the station - and for the first time what he’s just been inside: - the great red brick edifice that is Howrah - and beyond huge HOWRAH BRIDGE. An eerie, haunting 3:00 a.m. Stillnes From INSIDE comes a child’s SCREAM - which propels Saroo keep sprinting - away from the station - along the road -

- straight up the stairs to a vast forbidding bridge - hi tiny legs struggling to keep going upwards, upwards ... He reaches the top of the stairs. He looks ahead. This bridge, stretching into the distance, is the biggest thing he’s ever seen in his life. Few cars on the road. Few PEOPLE on the footpath. Polluti haze like a ghostly fog. It feels haunted. Ahead: a couple of Calcutta’s WILD DOGS potter about. The own this bridge at night. Saroo inches backwards, scared and wary.  15 He looks back down the stairs. No sign of the body snatch But ahead, beyond those dogs: it’s too daunting. Too haun Through the rails, down by the river bank, he sees: - CANDLES, flickering. That looks the safer option.

We follow Saroo from blackness - to those candles flicker 15 BABAS (HOLY MEN) sleep: dirty robes, matted beards, dreadlocks, red ochre faces. Peaceful. They sleep facing a small platform shrine to goddess Kali (the Destroyer). Bright painted Kali statue 4 feet high - fierce, frightening, astride her lion. Carefully, Saroo moves through the holy men, toward Kali. Four arms, garland of skulls, riding a lion. Spooky. At Kali’s feet, offerings: coconut shavings, pesos, nuts. Saroo looks at the men again; no one seems to be stirring He bows quickly to Kali, and sneaks some of the offerings Spies a sliver of unpopulated ground. He clambers in behind the small platform, lies down. Out trouble, out of sight. His own corner of this metropolis. His eyes getting sleepy. Watching the sleeping holy men - beyond them, the dark, wide river, flowing by. FADE TO BLACK. Silence - a beat - then the sound of men murmuring, chant

The chanting grows louder. Saroo’s eyes, dreamy, open - l in the chanting. [It will act as a strange breathing spac He stands. He comes out from behind the Kali shrine. The Babas face him, meditating, chanting. As if Saroo, th beside Kali on her lion, were a tiny god himself. Saroo walks through the holy men, down to the river's edg No real purpose. The chanting is haunting, extraordinary.  16 All the PEOPLE going through their morning rituals: bathi brushing their teeth, scrubbing pots. Saroo separate. Los Observing everyone. They all seem to know what they’re do

The chanting continues, as Saroo wanders, back at that pl from where he fled last night. It’s empty and desolate no He doesn’t look terrified. Just lost. He sees what he wan - on the ground, the cardboard that Wiry Boy gave him. He picks it up. His “bed”. Planning ahead. He drags it aw

location: ALONG THE RAILWAY TRACKS, HOWRAH STATION

text: Saroo wanders by the side of the tracks, with his cardboa sheet. Past the BLACK METAL POOLS where MEN and BOYS sift metals from construction waste. Then up a tiny path. He comes across a WOMAN (NOOR, 40) carrying tin lunch box She turns as they pass. Watches him.
It’s dangerous walking here. Saroo stops. Stands there, quietly, innocently.
You speak Bengali? Saroo doesn’t seem to understand the question.
(in Hindi) You speak Hindi? A beat. Saroo nods, Yes.
I got lost.
Where are you from?
Ganestlay.
Where is that?
Home.  17
I don’t know where that is. A beat. She seems concerned. Saroo, so vulnerable.
What is your name?
Saroo.
I am Noor. (beat) Are you hungry? She motions with the lunch boxes. Saroo nods, follows.
Saroo follows Noor up the stairs of her building -

- they come out onto the amazing rooftop - Saroo has neve been anywhere high before - Calcutta stretches before him (POV): the view reveals KIDS playing on LOWER ROOFTOPS - kites - a sense of community - the sounds of kids playing

- Come - She lives up here! He follows her into her rooftop shack INT. NOOR’S ROOFTOP HOME - CONTINUOUS (AFTERNOON) Saroo, wide-eyed, walks across to the windows -— (POV): amazing views across the RAILWAY YARDS; HOWRAH BRI in the distance; everywhere, golden afternoon light. INT. NOOR’S ROOFTOP HOME - LATER (LATE AFTERNOON) Saroo sits at a small table with Noor, shovelling lentils into his mouth from a plastic plate. To him, a feast. It’s as if he relaxes, a tiny notch. This woman feels saf
(ironic) Looks like you hate it! Saroo looks up, mouth full, smiles at the humour.  18
I make the lunches for all the men. (beat) You have to make a living.
I help my brother carry bales.
You do?
I help my mother carry rocks.

She works in a quarry? Saroo nods Yes. His mouth still full, going full throttle Noor gazes at him. Sadness. Compassion. From a TINY FRIDGE, she takes out an ORANGE SODA in a bot She opens it and hands it to him. Saroo looks down astonished at the bottle in his hands. H never had one of these. He looks up at her. She nods, Go He puts the bottle to his lips. Drinks. Winces at the bubbles. Looks up at her, and smiles. Another sip. Amazing. Amazing. Suddenly: an enormous burp Saroo could cry, he’s so amazed. Instead, they laugh. INT. NOOR’S ROOFTOP HOME - LATER (NIGHT) Naked Saroo, head to toe in soap suds, stands in a plasti tub in the corner, as Noor SCRUBS him vigorously. His body being pummeled. It’s not at all unpleasant. Noor ladles water, pours it over Saroo’s head. As the wat cascades and the suds wash away, he closes his eyes.

- and opens them, the water cascading off his face. REVERSE: he’s looking at Kamla, bathing him. Saroo blinks, looking at: Kamla’s face, as she concentrates on washing him. INT. NOOR’S ROOFTOP HOME - CONTINUOUS (NIGHT) Saroo blinks, looking at:  19 Noor’s face - as she concentrates on washing him. She takes his cheeks in her hand -

Open your mouth. She moves his lips, inspects his teeth and gums. INT. BEDROOM, NOOR’S ROOFTOP HOME - LATER (NIGHT) Saroo, curled up on the tiny bed in the corner. Noor pads blanket down on top of him. Luxury.
(her voice soothing) I know a man who is a very special man. His name is Rama. He knows many people. He will come tomorrow, to help you.
To find Ammi?
Yes, Ammi. You sleep now. The day couldn’t get any better. Saroo smiles, eyes heavy Then, surrendering to his tiredness, he’s out like a ligh

INT. BEDROOM, NOOR’S ROOFTOP HOME - MORNING Saroo opens his eyes. The light is blinding, almost heave He raises his head, looks through to the other room: - where a handsome, impeccably dressed MAN (RAMA, 40) sit with Noor at the table, finishing a small meal.
Oh, he is awake. Rama walks into the bedroom. Perches on the bed.
I wonder what worlds you have travelled in. That was such a sleep, young man.
(sitting up) You are Rama?
(smiles) Yes, but not the god. And I have been told you are lost.  20 Saroo nods meekly, yes.
I need to ask you some questions. And you need to tell me all that you can - so I can help you ... What is your name?
Saroo.
Saroo. And you are from...?
Ganestlay.
It’s not a name that is familiar to me. But we may be able to find it. What is your family name? Saroo looks up at the man, almost shameful. He doesn’t kn
It’s all right, it’s not important. Rama starts to lie down, and gestures Saroo to lie back d
Come lie down, I have come so far to see you. Saroo blinks twice. Is that a “no thanks” kind of questio He lies down, tentatively. Rama pulls him in. A tiny bed.
Tell me how you got here, Saroo.
I went to the station with my brother -
- and your brother is? -

- Guddu. And he went away. And he didn’t come back - - as Saroo talks, Rama casually strokes his hair - CLOSE, Saroo’s eyes: surely that’s not right - SAROO (CONT’D) - so I rested on the train. But I fell asleep. Then I couldn’t get off. And the train came here.  21 - Rama nods, murmurs encouragement, keeps stroking - - Noor watches, blankly, from across the room - SAROO (CONT’D) But I can’t find the train to get back.
Saroo, you’re a good boy. Are you a good boy? Saroo nods earnestly. But also subtly shifts his head. Rama sits up. Ruffles Saroo’s hair.
I’1l1 tell you what. I’11 be back tonight, and I’1l take you somewhere good.
To my mother?
Somewhere good. And from there we'll try to find your mother. These things are not always easy. Saroo nods, confused, hopeful. Rama stands.

Stand up for me. Let me see you. Saroo stands on the bed. Rama admires him, pulls his arms like a man admiring strength or beauty in a son. Or inspecting a horse. Saroo, passive, lets it happen. Rama holds out his hand. Saroo, clearly not practiced in art of hand-shaking, offers his tiny hand.
Say thank you to Rama.

Thank you. Rama leaves the bedroom, crosses the main room, kisses No goodbye - slight sexual overtone - and passes out the doo Saroo stands there on the bed, closely observing all this It’s all so strange. And not quite right. The faint sound of children playing, 0/S. INT. NOOR’S ROOFTOP HOME - LATER (DUSK) Saroo sits, eating, as Noor stirs dhal in a pot.  22 Another bottle of orange soda in front of him. Untouched. He stares at the bottle. Then at Noor. Busy with cooking, she half-sings along to some Bollywood song on the radio. She looks over to Saroo and smiles. He looks at the soda again. At Noor. Something stirring inside him - - and suddenly he simply ups from the table and makes a b for it - straight out the door. Noor SCREAMS - revealing the true animal she is.
- Saroo takes the stairs at lightning speed, Noor screami and chasing O/S behind him -— - around one landing, a MAN lurches at him - misses - - Saroo taking those steps faster that he’s ever run befo
Saroo BURSTS OUT onto the pathway outside the apartment building and scrambles away, up towards the city lights -
- and into the busy dusk streets. He runs. And runs, and runs, and runs —

- right up those stairs to the Howrah Bridge. (This time: trucks, cars, horns blaring, countless PEOPLE. No wild do And this time, Saroo keeps right on running - zigzagging way through the CROWDS, a bundle of pure determination. His little fists clenched. Glancing back, still fearful. A marathon runner. And now we hear only his breath.

We TRACK him in PROFILE: framing consistency, fluid fades consistency of tracking speed mean it all looks like one shot, even though B/G changes and it’s many different sho As if he’s running through all of India. FADE TO BLACK. OVER the blackness, the sound of RAIN. It pours. It pours  23
Then a tiny voice, coming up over the rain:
Sorry. Sorry.
TIGHT on Saroo’s face - DARK, in the shadows - we’ve no i where it is - his face ever grimier. It’s raining heavily. In the shadowy recess, he’s whisper
Sorry. Sorry. I'll come back. I’m sorry, Ammi ...

SUDDEN contrast from the darkness to brilliant white ligh A surreal landscape: mythological, prehistoric - rocky, barren - white dust swirling like a fine talcum mist. Saroo, scrambling over the rocks, like the first human ev

Good boy. Saroo starts helping - lifts a rock far too heavy for him
(laughing as he struggles) Not this one, Saroo. Get those little ones. He gathers a couple of rocks, drops them into her wooden
Small ones at the back. That’s it. Look at your muscles! Saroo grins, flexes his muscles like a bodybuilder.
(laughs) Good boy. Good boy.  24

Heart-wrenching - Saroo’s attempts at a nest, at belongin A filthy blanket; water bottle; broken toy car; mussel sh And another cardboard sheet. Which he’s lying on now, on belly, a torn Indian Vogue propped against the wall. Saroo parks the toy car at the base of the Swiss mountain a Breitling watch ad. He loads the seashell onto the roof the car and drives it away, making little-child NOISES. He fills the mussel shell with dirt and tiny pebbles, pus it to the corner, tips the contents out. Like Kamla’s hod
Good boy. Good boy. That’s a good boy. Good boy. AUDIO: the rain easing.

The sun’s out, everything dripping. Saroo clambers down. see how ingenious his nest is: a 4-feet-cubed concrete re between two pylons, 8 feet off the ground, hidden from vi The crows look down on him from the telegraph wires.

Saroo fossicks by the shore, where the garbage ebbs and b His little “scavenger bag” slung over his shoulder. A DEAD BODY - a crippled beggar, lips blue, eyes lifeless stares at the sky in a death grimace. Saroo stares for a moment. And then steps over it. He finds a bent spoon. Inspects it. It looks like some ru relic from the Raj - an English serving spoon. Pleased, he puts it in the scavenger bag.

Saroo sits in a narrow traffic island in the middle of a crazy busy street - buses and trucks in all directions. He takes out the spoon, studies it again, straightens it. Reaching back into the scavenge bag, he places a few grai of rice and corn on the spoon. Across the road at a cafe table, a MAN (pleasant-looking, student, 22, a book and cup of chai in front of him) watc fascinated. Saroo feeds himself off the spoon, imagining a HUGE mouth  25 To the man it’s heartbreaking - he’s drawn in by Saroo’s “play”. At that moment their eyes meet. The man smiles.
Saroo sits at a desk, tiny and bewildered in “officialdom as the café man speaks to a POLICE OFFICIAL (50).

He speaks Hindi - not a word of Bengali - so he must be a long way from home. When I ask where he’s from, he keeps saying “Ganestlay”. It means nothing to me. The official nods, walks over to an old WALL MAP of India

(to Saroo) Now this ... “Ganestlay” —- (pointing to all of India) Do you think you might have a rough idea where it is? Saroo - the little prince of cluelessness. POLICE OFFICIAL (CONT’D) Do you know which province? It would help us a lot if you knew the province. Even as the words come out of his mouth, he understands t stupidity of the question. But he hovers there, in hope. Saroo stares at the map - that distinct triangle of India then the official, as if they’re both enormous blank wall The official sits. Glances at the café man. POLICE OFFICIAL (CONT’D) Let's try something else. Do you know your family name?
FLASH! Saroo’s photo is taken.

The official at a counter (Saroo on a bench, B/G, with th café man) as a hardened OFFICER (he’s seen it all) takes approximately five seconds to read Saroo’s two-page FILE. STAMP! He stamps the file “LOST”. Staples the PHOTO to th cover. Pulls out a separate page, Indian-bureaucracy-styl  26
(hands official the file) That’s for ISSA. (hands him the page) That’s for Liluah.
(slight frown) Really?
(shrugs; not my problem) While they process him. ON THE POLICE OFFICIAL: he knows this is not great. He composes himself, turns, smiles to Saroo and Café Man.
They've found him a home - while they look. The man smiles, relieved. Ruffles Saroo’s hair.

location: POLICE VAN, STREET TO LILUAH GATE

text: We FOLLOW a dirty van down a narrow road along a high wal topped with barbed wire and embedded broken glass.

In the back of the van, Saroo and four sullen STREET KIDS sit, spooked, silent, tense, waiting - a haunting vigil o expectation as the van rattles along. (AUDIO, EXT:) The van’s horn HONKS; an iron gate creaks o
Shuffling sounds, as the children move - and outside, the various noises and echoes of a world we are about to reve

We emerge from the darkness, following the terrified chil following the barking guard into the bleak, sun-drenched courtyard of the high-walled complex. A shiver-up-the-spine wrongness about this decrepit, fort like place - no sense of a connection to the outside worl Lonely chairs and rubbish lie on top of the wire-mesh “ro  27 They pass rows of cells; children’s EYES stare from the d On Saroo: what is this nightmare? He was desperate in Calcutta; but there’s nothing but sorrow and suffering he

Saroo sits frozen, wary, on what passes for a bed. Five other CHILDREN on beds, like spectres in the gloom. Everyone looks traumatized; nobody speaks. FADE TO BLACK. OVER THE BLACKNESS we hear: the sounds of LOCKS OPENING, CHAINS CLANGING, the big IRON FRONT GATE CREAKING OPEN - FOOTSTEPS across the courtyard - two MEN talking - coming closer, closer - and downstairs, into the quiet building

FADE UP: a sweet 5-YEAR-OLD GIRL (AMITA) lies in bed in t stillness, staring over at Saroo with huge unblinking eye Saroo stares back. The sounds come closer. Saroo turns and watches as the two men - one a GUARD, the other a well-dressed OUTSIDER - stride past the open door A door opens (0/S, AUDIO). Whimpering - a scuffle - shout Then Saroo catches a glimpse of a HAUNTED BOY (8) being dragged past the door by the men. Terror in the boy’s eye Saroo so wide-eyed and wide awake in the dark night. AUDITORY SEQUENCE (while on Saroo): a confusing auditory nightmare. Beatings. Cries of anguish. Rape. Amita simply stares across to Saroo. Then after a time, she closes her eyes. Saroo stares at the ceiling, eyes wide. The noises contin
Saroo shovels the thin gruel into his mouth in cowed sile Amita by his side, doing the same.
What is your name?
Amita.  28 Saroo notices a GUARD escorting a kindly-looking lady (MR SOOD, 45) with files in hand, who seems to be pointing an talking about particular kids with the guard.
Does anybody ever leave here, Amita?
I've seen it.
What will you do when you leave? Pause.
I'd like to own a watch one day. Long pause.
Fifteen CHILDREN, nerves on edge, straining to get it rig A SEVERE TEACHER barks the Sanskrit alphabet, pointing to letters on the blackboard as these illiterate kids repeat

Kaa ... Gaa ... Naa ... Daa Kaa ... Gaa ... Naa ... [etc] Saroo is earnestly trying to learn. He spots the haunted from last night. A wild look in the boy's eyes: blank, an All the children except for Haunted Boy are duly repeatin the alphabet. Saroo looking sideways, fascinated by him. Haunted Boy swaying back and forwards, rubbing his hair a forehead, looking like a pressure cooker about to explode He upturns his desk, WAILS a primal howl of pure distress

What is this? The teacher starts raining blows upon Haunted Boy. At first Haunted Boy just takes it, through clenched teet - then he goes completely crazy, and fights back. The teacher fights back even harder, screaming for help. All the kids back away in a wide circle, scared, horrifie Saroo, trying to shrink within himself.  29 As the horrible struggle continues and two MALE TEACHERS in and help beat down Haunted Boy - Saroo watching wide-e - LIVE SOUND FADES, and a beautiful, haunting little Hind folk song rises - Amita’s voice in PRE-LAP -

Saroo lies listening, soothed, as Amita softly sings. The song becomes the AUDIO “BED” as we travel over the landsc of the various CHILDREN in this holding room of lost soul hands covered in scabs, eyes all staring. Listening. Not a child in this room has any idea of their fate. The holds it all together: for this one moment, all are sooth ON SAROO: gradually, his eyes close. FADE TO BLACK. Over the black, a SUPER: THREE MONTHS LATER
JOLTING AWAKE out of the dreamy song is Saroo, being shak
You. You have to come. Sleepy Saroo is confused: what on earth could this mean?
We travel BEHIND Saroo as he’s led into an outer room balcony. Kindly Mrs Sood stands as he enters.

Good morning, Saroo. He takes her in. Angel of Mercy or Angel of Death? She’s woman he briefly noticed on that first day in the mess ha MRS SOOD (CONT’D) My name is Mrs Sood. Sit. Sit. (he sits, warily) I run an organization called ISSA. (in English:) The “Indian Society for Sponsorship and Adoption.” (then says it in Hindi -) Saroo listens, brow furrowed, a little astonished that th woman is talking to him as if he’s an adult.  30

This place is a home for the deformed. For the mentally ill. For juvenile delinquents. Or where parents who cannot cope leave their children. But you are none of those. You are lost. I like to make sure there’s no one here who should be - elsewhere. That’s why I’m here. Annoying them. Helping you. (beat; opening his file) I've been investigating your case for a while now - we even placed this ad in all the Calcutta newspapers when you arrived here - She shows him a cutting of a small classified ad in Sansk with that photo of Saroo we recognize from the police sta and, in English, “Indian Society for Sponsorship and Adoption, 1 Kyd Street, Calcutta”. Saroo stares at the photo of himself. Fascinated.
Fifteen million people read this. That’s many, many people. (beat) Not one reply, I’m afraid.
I came from far away.
Not one reply. It’s a harsh truth and she doesn’t hide it. Saroo, desper
Ammi? [Mummy ]
No ... no Ammi. Saroo just sits there. Shocked. Silence. A long beat.
Saroo, do you know where Australia is? Saroo looks confused.
We found a family there who could look after you. As Saroo pulls back - What? - Mrs Sood gets that he understands this means the search is over.
Come. Sit here. Saroo says nothing. Falls deeper into numbness. Mrs Sood pulls him onto her lap. Shows him a little FLIP of photos, sent by the prospective parents.

Would you like to see them? (flipping through) Look. That’s “John”. That’s “Sue”. This is the house. [etc.] Saroo studies them, intensely. ON THE PHOTOS: John and Su white, smiling. Saroo’s room. The living room. The garden
They live on a little island called Tasmania. Full of very nice people. (beat) They look nice, don’t they? Saroo shakes his head meekly, No. Mrs Sood strokes his hair gently, once. Gets serious.
Saroo. You cannot stay here. A tear rolls down Saroo’s face.
I want Ammi.
I know you do. It’s hard. She sets him down. Takes out the photo of John and Sue.
Will you take this? Look after it, until the next time I see you? Saroo nods bravely. Takes the photo in his tiny hand.
Don’t lose it. Saroo nods, slips it into his little back pocket. He walk the door, head down, dejected. He turns. A huge question - you can see it in every fibre of his be
Did you really look your hardest? She nods solemnly.  32
Under every rock. Saroo stands there. Hanging onto her gaze like a lifeboat
You can hold them in your heart, always. But now you have a new home, if you want it. Saroo looks away. A deep breath, almost a sigh.

Two KIDS play a joyless game - others pace the yard and l B/G - while Saroo sits against a decayed wall at the yard edge. Amita beside him - holding that photo of Sue and Jo ON THE PHOTO: already, it’s battered and frayed and folde Amita studies it, with the fiercest interest. Saying noth but knowing everything. Nodding. Knowing he’s going. Know how lucky he is. She looks up at the clouds through the wire mesh open roo Saroo looks up there too. A silent communion between the Then - almost formally - Amita takes the tiny Ganesh medallion from around her neck. Puts it around Saroo’s ne Not cheap and touristy, but ancient-looking, and worn - almost like something dug up from an archeological dig.
Ganesh will look after you. He’s the god of new beginnings. Saroo takes her hand in his. They sit there, side by side

We TRACK through a pleasant, simply furnished hotel suite find Saroo and two other orphans sitting, a little stiffl at a table set in western style: knife, fork, spoon in th proper order, butter dish, salt and pepper shakers, etc. As they eat, Mrs Sood is giving them a last-minute lesson
(in English) “Fork”. Saroo proudly holds up his fork, grinning.
Good. “Knife”? The orphan boy holds up the knife.  33 Mrs Sood points to the salt shaker.
(tentative) “Salt...”
(in English) Salt. Good. She points to the pepper. Orphan Girl racks her brains.
(jumping in) “Peppa...” It’s the funniest word they’ve ever heard. The three chil giggle, repeating the word.

CLOSE with Saroo as he steps into the enormous interior o Qantas jet. Awestruck. Everything so gleaming and new - j like Saroo himself, wearing that hilarious “Tasmania and territories” tee-shirt from the Long Way Home book cover. His minder settles him and sits beside him. On Saroo: what a world. The seat. The seatbelt. The magaz pocket. The window shade. The overhead light.
Would he like a Kids’ Kit?
Thank you. She hands the kit to the minder. Then an extra surprise:
Would you like a Cadbury bar, little man?
(taking it from her) Cadbury. He looks at the minder, who nods Yes, you can open it. Saroo opens the purple wrapper. Blown away by what chocol looks like up close. He bites into it.
TAKE-OFF. We study this tiny 5-year-old, glued to the win as the plane lifts off.  34
POV from window: all of Calcutta. So tiny down there.

The astonishing view from 30,000 feet. Saroo’s been glued that window for hours. The earth is vast. Saroo pulls down the window blind. Pulls it up again. Saroo turns, looks at his sleeping minder. Looks back at window. Blind down, blind up. Looks back out the window.
We're CLOSE behind Saroo’s shoulder as the minder guides along a corridor, flanked by an AIRPORT OFFICIAL. We round the corner of the corridor and enter -
- where JOHN (32) and SUE (29) BRIERLEY stand up anxiousl Everyone just stands there for a moment - so tentative -
Hello. I’m Swarmina.

(softly) I’m John. This is Sue. Saroo has retreated behind Swarmina’s leg - he holds on f dear life and peers out shyly. Wide-eyed. First boy on Ma Sue kneels gently. A lifetime of waiting brims in her eye She looks down on Saroo with as much astonishment as he h
Hi there. Saroo still clutches the half-eaten Cadbury bar from earl
(deadpan) Cadbury. It doesn’t get more awkward. Or beautiful.

It’s a Cadbury, John.  35 I/E. CAR / THE BRIERLEY’S STREET - DAY We're in the car with our new nuclear family, in the back seat with Saroo (POV). He looks at the passing rows of br suburban homes - neat lawns - sprinklers. So unlike India Sue watches Saroo in the central mirror: his curiosity an his amazement.
We’re behind Saroo as he enters the house, awed, alert, curious. Sue and John gently prod -

That’s okay - have a look around - Saroo is goggle-eyed. Sue gives running commentary wherev he goes. Whatever he looks at. This is the Living room. That's the television. [etc...] The clean white benches. The shiny refrigerator. Saroo steps up to the fridge. He looks back to Sue: May I He opens the door. The colourful glory of western groceri Stands there, mouth open, simply stunned. Shuts it gently INT. SAROO’S BEDROOM, BRIERLEY HOME - MINUTES LATER (DAY) Saroo’s bedroom. A box of toys. Saroo looks up at Sue and John, not quite believing his eyes: Can I touch these?
They’re yours.
You can play with them. But Saroo just stands there, lost in a moment of fully ta in his parents. John Brierley. Sue Brierley. White Martia Saroo blinks twice.

(kneeling) Here you go. (pushing a truck) You have a go, son. Saroo picks it up. Simply studies its wheels. Spins one. He’s too overwhelmed, too shy, to play immediately. Looks at his parents again.  36

See how the doors open. Look. Like this. John demonstrates the truck doors. Saroo likes that. He o and closes the tiny doors. He puts the truck on the ground - pushes it along. Gets l in the activity. Then he looks up. As he takes in the room once more, something on the wall catches his attention: - a detailed MAP OF INDIA. Saroo recognizes the triangle, that dense information, though he can no more understand written English than he could the Bengali on that map in police station back in Calcutta -
That's right. That’s where you came from. Look. This is India. This is Calcutta, here.
(one word he recognizes) Cal-cutta. He stares politely at the incomprehensible map.
Dinner time: Saroo nervous, polite, calm, as they eat. He barely above the table. Taking in the place settings. As Saroo chews, he looks up at his new parents. Grins.
(pointing) Peppa. Sue and John share a proud smile.
That's right. That’s the pepper.
Sue ladles water over Saroo. He’s fascinated with everyth the water, the warmth, this gentle woman, these bath toys
Close your eyes. She motions to him: close your eyes. For an instant, he looks at her warily. Remembering Noor.  37

Go on. It’s okay. He looks into her eyes. He has to trust. He can trust. He closes his eyes. Sue pours a saucepan of water SLOWLY over his head. The S comes off him. It’s like some exotic baptism. You can see whole body - his whole being - relax. He opens his eyes.
(eager, encouraging) Good? Saroo smiles.

You’ve come so far. Haven’t you? My little one. He stares up at her with those huge dark eyes. SUE (CONT’D) I don’t imagine it’s been easy. One day, you make sure to tell me all about it. Tell me everything. Who you are. I'll always listen. He squeezes the alligator. It SQUEAKS. He pulls back, amu Sue notices John at the door - he has been quietly standi there the whole time - and a beautiful warmth spreads bet the three. So this is what it feels like - to be a family
Down there, a small YACHT races towards a sheltered bay. Over this, a SUPER: ONE YEAR LATER.

The modest boat - lovingly maintained - skips across the water. Her name - SUZIE - painted on the side. John teach Saroo how to sail. Saroo is deeply absorbed - his little face earnest. Sue - wind in her hair - watches them with unconcealed delight.
CUT IN HARD on little Saroo diving into frame, making an overdramatic lunge, catching a ball on the soft sand.  38

Howzat! The Brierleys play cricket on a curve of white sand, at t extraordinarily beautiful Wineglass Bay. The small family boat is moored nearby, in the azure water. With a child’s wooden cricket bat, Sue hits the ball high the air in a graceful arc that forces Saroo to really spr
(excited commentator) It’s going for six! No, young Saroo’s under it! - Saroo leaps for the ball again - dives into the water’s e as he catches it -
Howzat!
Bravo!
(commentator) Ohhhh! Saroo Brierley has done the impossible! Australia wins on the final ball of the day! Let’s look at the slow motion replay!
Mum! Mum, look at me! Saroo’s victory dance. His English comes naturally now. Laughing, Sue gets her camera - Saroo poses - a miniature hero - for a victory pic.

CLOSE on a child’s drawing - a house, a tree, the sun, tw adults, a brown child - and another brown face, looking o from an airplane window high above. WIDER: Saroo holding up the drawing like a banner - a kin “Welcome” offering. Pointing at the figures -—
Mum. Dad. Me. Mantosh. Sue and John, expectant. But not as nervous as last year. MANTOSH (8) enters with the same minder from last year.
Hello again! Saroo - my goodness! (beat) This is Mantosh.  39 Mantosh looks wild and feral - something not quite right. Saroo sees it instantly: sees it before John and Sue.

Mantosh - I’m John. This is Sue. And this is your brother Saroo. Say hello, Saroo. Saroo says nothing; gently hands the drawing to Mantosh. Mantosh doesn’t even take it, doesn’t even look at it. Saroo, perplexed, glances at Sue. The minder smiles at Sue. But you can see she’s had a tou 24 hours, and knows there’s something’s wrong with this k AUDIO (B/G, faint): John and Sue make small-talk with the minder, along the lines of “You have a nice flight?” etc. But down here at kid level, all of Saroo’s focus is on th wired boy whose eyes dart crazily, whose hands are scarre and scabbed. Saroo is basically thinking, “What the hell we got here?” [In Mantosh, we get the visual and behavioral echoes with Haunted Boy in Liluah too. ] INT. SAROO’S BEDROOM, BRIERLEY HOME - DAY Saroo stands frozen and freaked out in his own bedroom, e wide open - listening to a great commotion along the hall Saroo leans to his open door - peeks out -

REVERSE of that: a sliver of the chaos in the living room - (Saroo’s POV) Sue in silhouette, frozen - as beyond her Mantosh screams like a banshee for no apparent reason. A child's cricket bat flies across the room, clattering aga the china cabinet - as John lunges to protect it -
Woh woh woh woh! Hang on, sunshine - Mantosh ransacking his own new toys - Tasmanian devil sty
Careful with the furniture, mate. Mantosh starts to hit himself, screaming. Losing breath. Sue and John try to calm him.
C’mon. Breathe. Deep breaths.  40 BACK ON SAROO: in his sliver of doorway, watching the sce up the hallway, he simply CLOSES HIS EYES. CUT TO BLACK.

location: DARK HALLWAY, INTO KITCHEN, BRIERLEY HOME

text: We TRACK OUT OF THE BLACKNESS along the hall, into the da living room - and the OPEN KITCHEN over there. A night light in the kitchen illuminates Sue, standing at sink. Still. Her arms hanging limp. Exhausted. Mute. Saroo stands behind her, watching. (She hasn’t heard him. He steps beside her. Reaches up, takes her hand. She snaps out of it, looks down on him. It’s all right, s the look on his face. A private communion. The son comforting the mother. Then, if remembering her duty to look after him, Sue pulls Saro close, cradles his head. They stand there, a silent table MUSIC (PRE-LAP into next scene) rises over end of this, i

Deep blue water, infused with glints of sunlight. Saroo (now 26) breaks the surface. Contented. Relaxed. Completely at home in the water, he floats onto his back, at one with the sea and the sun. This is paradise... Super: 25 YEARS LATER He swims smoothly to the shore. Hauls his sailboard uprig
We track high above a car as it glides down the freeway -

Saroo, John and Sue sit in a busy restaurant - glass wall wine glasses tinkling, sunlight bouncing off the harbour. There’s a fourth place-setting, untouched. Clearly this i huge moment - their son is leaving. John pours the champa Saroo, observing the ritual. Sue, her eyes sparkling, to Saroo, re: the champagne - isn’t this exciting?
It’s only Melbourne...  4l
(jokes) It’s across the water. They hold their glasses up. Respect and care in this fami
Saroo. Beautiful boy. May this bring you all you can wish for.
And then some.
Thanks Mum. Thanks Dad.
You came into our lives.
- Mum! -
I’m not finished. You were more than we ever hoped for. On Saroo: Okay, Mum’s getting serious. Head down — embarrassed, but touched.
More work, that’s for sure. They laugh. SUE (CONT’D) From the moment we first saw you - She takes John’s hand.
Those great big eyes - Sue and John smile at each other.
And now look at you - just look at you...
You’re a good lad, Saroo.
We're proud of you, and excited for you, for this new chapter.
(toasts) To success.  42 At this moment the WAITER comes up.
(on the unused setting) Are you still waiting on someone? Or can I take this away?
You can take it away.
You can leave it, thanks.
No, take it. The waiter, uncertain.
(tight) I'd like to keep it, thanks. Beat. Well, that decides it.
You don’t really think he’1l turn up, do you?
Just let it be, son. Sue puts on her brave smile. Takes another sip of champag
(to John) This is a nice one, love. John puts his hand on her hand. Saroo looks lovingly at Sue. She’s brave and beautiful.
Saroo pulls up at a run-down shack that sits alone in a h eucalyptus forest by the sea - an isolationist’s dream.
We follow Saroo as he steps through the open front door i Mantosh’s forlorn home.

Mantosh? As Saroo walks straight through to the back door - it’s n big house - we take in the bare-bones, rundown interior -  43 - Saroo notes, in passing, all the messy drug paraphernal on the “coffee table” (an old door on two milk crates) -

- through to the back - and there, in a patch of sunlight the unkempt, scrappy yard, sits ADULT MANTOSH on a log. Smoking a hand-rolled cigarette, drinking instant coffee. Saroo comes over. Wariness between the two. Mantosh: wiry edgy, nervy. Static electricity comes off this guy.
Yeah, sorry I didn’t make lunch. Beat. Saroo, edgy.
What’s the course again?
Hotel management.
So you’re gonna learn to, what - manage a hotel? (beat) Well, have fun. Saroo doesn’t answer.
Any bills you need to pay?
Some cash’d be good. This is not even taken seriously.
You're on your own now.
I’m good at that. (beat) Hey, you can give me a job when you come back.
Cut the shit. Just - please, could you not do anything while I’m gone -
- yeah, yeah -  44
- that’s going to make mum even more unhappy.
(incredulous) Mate. Why do you think I stay away?
MUSIC. CLEAN POV of a TARMAC, falling away as we lift off
High above this luscious island. The green wilderness of Tasmania. The ocean, coming into view.
CLOSE on Saroo: at his window, looking down over that oce Reflective. The nomad, off again. He pulls the window bli down. Then up. Down. Up. Didn’t he do that once long ago?
Well-lit stage. An impressive, modern feel. Mid-address, PROVOST welcomes 100 NEW STUDENTS to an elite course at t Royal Melbourne College of Hotel Management.

You've been selected from around the world. A world that’s opening up faster than we could ever have imagined. ON Saroo: he scans the room. Students of all races. He sp a CLUSTER OF INDIAN STUDENTS. PROVOST (0.S.) (CONT’D) We see ourselves as the United Nations of hospitality schools, and we like to think we teach a balanced and global perspective. - Saroo studies the Indian students. We feel ever so slight his intrigue - as memories awaken from the deep. PROVOST (0.8) (CONT’D) You’re here because you have a dream. We're here to help you make that dream a reality.  45

Induction over. The aisle between the seats is crowded. Saroo shuffles along shoulder to shoulder with other stud of many races. He hears fragments of Hindi - it strikes him how many Ind students there are. He nods neutral hellos to them. Saroo eavesdrops as an IN STUDENT on her cell phone excitedly calls her Ammi. Saroo is stuck at the end of a row. Opposite him - also s - is a beautiful young woman - LUCY (late 20's). She meet his eye. They step forward together. A mirror-moment.
Open MID on Lucy - we’re in a round-robin discussion in a tutorial of about fifteen STUDENTS, assorted ages and backgrounds. A non-Anglo TUTOR.

- so I saw first-hand how the hospitality industry brings infrastructure to communities that really need it. But I also saw the problems that causes. Which is why community groups really need to be involved, every step of the way. And taken seriously. And I thought - I could help give them a voice. Saroo, watching, listening, entranced by this beautiful, idealistic woman.
Not try to prevent progress, but convince developers there are benefits to being sustainable and community oriented.
(amused, encouraging) Why not think big?
(laughs) Absolutely. In return, the labour force would be more consistent and better trained and more motivated. Win-win.
So you want to be ... The tutor considers.  46
- a community liaison consultant?
That sounds good! Done. She looks to Saroo: his turn next.
I want to run hotels that put all the profits into my pocket. Some laughter. Some frowns. Saroo was only joking. Lucy grins at him. A tickle of chemistry.
Let’s start with where you’re from.
Tassie.
“Tazzy"?
Tasmania. Across the water.
So born in Australia.
(resistant) Umm ... Kolkata.
I have cousins that live there. They're quite mad.
Which part? Saroo’s sudden discomfort. It’s been a long time, and eve talking about it is stirring up memories.
I'm adopted. I’m not really Indian. He inadvertently comes across as a little rude - as if he wouldn’t want to be Indian. Bharat and Prama feel it. Luc dispels the growing tension.
You love cricket though, right?
Of course.  47
You don’t support the Aussies, do you?
Only the Aussies, mate. Bharat and Prama look alarmed.
This is going to be interesting! They all smile.

(getting it back on track) And why are you doing this course, Saroo? What do you hope to get out of it? Saroo refocuses, ponders the question. He smiles at the t - trying to find the elusive answer. EXT. FLINDER’S STREET, MELBOURNE - DAY Saroo walking in the afternoon light. A metropolis strang like Howrah. The hum and energy, the traffic, distant tra sounds. INT. SAROO’S STUDENT APARTMENT - DAY Silence. A sudden sense of isolation. Saroo goes to the window. Ten stories down, the busy city with its enticing energy.

Beers in hand, Saroo climbs the exterior stairs of a 70’s block, where a long balcony leads along the third floor. As he reaches the landing, he sees Lucy at the far end - coming up the opposite identical stairs. Like mirrors aga Struck by the serendipity again - and Saroo struck by Luc beauty - they burst into smiles. As they arrive at the door, Bollywood music can be heard. They can’t resist the “mirror” temptation - they knock on door in unison, cracking up.
