Any of it. He moves past her - INT. LUKE’S PLACE - CONTINUOUS - and back into the loud party - and out of here - - Lucy hot on his heels -
Saroo! Luke, watching them head for the door. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE LUKE’S PLACE - CONTINUOUS (NIGHT) Saroo just wants to get away. Lucy follows.
Don’t do this.
You don’t get it.
You have to face reality.
What do you mean, “reality”?
The reality that you’re ruining your life! That you’re not even here!  75
Do you have any idea what it’s like, knowing my real brother and mother spend every day of their lives looking for me?
(genuinely bewildered) What?
How every day they scream my name. (beat) And I feel their touch. I see their faces. Can you imagine the pain they must be in, not knowing where I am? Twenty-five years, Luce. Twenty-five!
Why haven’t you ever told me this was happening?
And we swan about in our privileged lives. Pretending. It makes me sick. Lucy is speechless.
(faint, soft) I never stopped you ... It’s as if Saroo suddenly sees her pain properly. And is brought back to earth. The air in him deflating.
Listen -. Lucy -. I’m sorry -. I can’t do this -. (beat) You deserve more -
- don’t! Don’t you dare. Her eyes fill with tears.
This is on you! Not me. Saroo can’t deal with her pain. He takes off. This time, doesn’t follow.
Saroo walks the streets like a tormented soul.  76 He can’t live in two worlds at once. He has to choose. Slowly, his despair becomes defiance. He’s made his choice.
Kamla wanders the streets, distressed.
Saroo! (JUMP CUTS.) She’s beside herself. Searching empty lanewa
Saroo! Saroo! Faces everywhere. Kamla looks like a crazy lady. People peer out from their windows and doorways. She neve stops, the camera always moving. A mother in panic.
First hints of light. Saroo just wandering. He seems drained. All movement, no thought.
Kamla is by the river, amongst the prayer, the smoke, the chanting. Kids in the river, swimming. Washing. She hunts their faces.
Saroo! WIDE: she searches in this enormous landscape - strange, poetic, haunting - the PEOPLE like ants ...
Saroo! Her voice drowned out by the sound of a train, passing ov the river.

TWO MONTHS LATER. SOUND of the sea. Bright marine light. track through the house. It’s virtually empty. The atmosp of a squat. No sign of homeliness, of warmth - of Lucy. A mattress on the living room floor. A master map of Indi the wall. Piles of print-outs - lists of railway stations some marked-up - most still pristine. Images of water tow train platforms, under-passes. Saroo - long hair, beard - has surrendered to his obsessi MUSIC starts - continues into a series of HARD CUTS: - Scrolling; waiting for the pixels to resolve. - A blue “train station” symbol. - CLOSER IN: a formless, satellite-image town. - On Saroo: studying its features. No, that’s not it. He stands - grabs a blue pin - sticks it into the map. - leans back into the screen. Reads the next town - - enters the name. - blue train station symbol. - Another town, the surrounds of the train station. - He grabs another blue pin - sticks it into the map. - Scroll. Symbol. Station. Pin. - Scroll. Symbol. Station. Pin. It becomes a rapid MONTAGE. Sound of someone hammering on front door.
Mantosh is at the door. He looks nervous, desperate, stan there counting coins in his hand. He bangs harder on the door.
Saroo, ya bastard! Silence. Mantosh, listening.  78
Saroo! (beat) Mate, can you lend us fifty bucks? CLOSE on Mantosh, sweating there at the door. He doesn’t good. Mantosh gives up knocking, leaves.
Yeah, whatever, dude.

Saroo spies out of the window. As Mantosh heads off down the beach, he’s joined by a DRU MATE, who has been lurking somewhere near. The mate looks to Mantosh, inquisitive, Well? Mantosh jus shakes his head, No go. They walk away. Saroo turns. Guddu is there, also watching Mantosh. Saroo and Guddu look at each other. Saroo returns to his search.

TWO MONTHS LATER. Saroo - his hair longer, his beard wild moves slowly down the aisle of a stationery shop - puttin boxes of COLOURED FLAG PINS into a basket. He’s out of place in this vivid Charlie & the Chocolate Factory world. He stops at the pen section, testing high-lighters. Throw some different-coloured boxes of those in his basket. At the counter, as the items are scanned, we study Saroo’ face. He looks exhausted. Doesn’t notice when the CASHIER smiles at him.
Same project? Saroo nods, with an air of defeat.
Saroo walks along the sand with his shopping. Past rows o suburban houses, their blank windows reflecting the sea.  79
Little Saroo on the tracks, proudly holds his pregnant be of coal. Guddu bustles over to him.
Come on, hurry. Little Saroo looks so happy, as they trot off together.
Saroo crosses the sand to the house. His face determined
Saroo’s POV: the world moves past in a watercolour blur - ochre country, hills, mountains, trees -

ON SCREEN: tracking railway lines, flying above them - station after station. Saroo ZOOMS in. His hopes up. He counts the platforms with his finger. NO: yet again, that’s not it. Disappointed, he zooms back out. GOOGLE SCREEN JUMP CUTS: train track after train track .. Platform after platform... SOUND of a real train, approaching, coming under us:
Kamla walks up to the very edge of railway track just as train rips past very fast. An endless stream of carriages - the noise and speed viol crazy, dangerous - but Kamla shows no fear.
Saroo! Saroo! Her screams drowned out by the racket of the train. She i hell, but cannot - will not - give up.

Saroo mirrors her desperation. He gets a beer, stares at map. A new colour being used now, for a new search zone. About 15% of the search complete.  80 He’s suddenly aware it’s the dead of night. He feels like only soul awake.

TWO MONTHS LATER. CLOSE on a table filled with leftover Chinese food (where some people have just finished and le the table), when a SMALL INDIAN HAND comes into frame, th fingers scooping up the food - - we TRACK up the arm to reveal Guddu - wolfing down the with bare hands, greatly enjoying it - and all the while staring across to - - Saroo (other side of the food court) - who stares right back, sitting in front of his untouched (western) meal.

Saroo steps onto the escalator. The lights and muzak of capitalism definitely not working wonders for him. As he descends: there is someone ascending. It’s Lucy. Sh looks grounded and somehow resolved. They approach each other. Lucy sees him. Alarm in her eyes. He looks like a crazy m Saroo swings across, from his escalator to hers. As always, drawn by her vivid gaze, her intense life-forc

Lucy follows Saroo up the stairs. She walks in and stops at the sight of Saroo’s “Project”. It’s mind-blowing. An entire wall is plastered in charts, train-timetables, station-name-lists, grainy images from Google Earth. On the Master Wall is a big map - surrounded by smaller o And all the pins ... The floor layered in books, notes, clothes, take-away containers. We go closer to the Master Wall with Lucy, inspecting it. Dense trails of colored drawing pins on the 400km search radius - different colors for different train lines. WALL KEY: green pin = Mumbai line, red pin = Nagpur line But our dominant visual information: in the past 6 months Saroo has covered a fraction of the search radius. The in circle only.  81 Saroo responds to Lucy’s look of fascination and alarm.
Theoretically it’s not infinite. She just stares at him.
Lucy - I’m sorry.
Saroo and Lucy sit on the beach.
What was she like?

Beautiful. He’s lost in the memory of it - staring out to the ocean, drawing patterns in the sand. SAROO (CONT’D) I’ve been visiting her. (beat) Every night I walk those streets home - home from the dam, home from the station. I know every single step of the way. And I imagine that I’m whispering in her ear. “I’m here. It’s all right.” Silence. Lucy knows what he means - she’s imagined the sa thing with her own mother. SAROO (CONT’D) How was New York?
Same old, same old.
And now? Lucy grins. There is good news.
Our funding came through.

That’s great! See, they know how good you are. An awkward silence.  82 Lucy can’t resist a moment longer - she reaches out and c his beard with her fingers. Her touch is like manna from heaven. SAROO (CONT’D) I miss you - A pained beat -
I saw your mom. She hasn’t been well. He doesn’t want to hear this.
She'd freak if she saw me like this.
You underestimate her. A long, sad pause.
She needs you.
A monsoon day - in the middle of a torrential downpour. A MERCHANT (55) loads a giant WATERMELON into Saroo’s arm

Hurry! Hurry! Hurry! Go! - the merchant keeping dry, looking for a gap in the traf launching Saroo onto the wet road, with his green boulder - Saroo, ill-prepared for the task, as traffic whizzes by almost immediately his feet slide out from under him - - and a MOTORBIKE blares out of nowhere, careening down u Saroo - too late - the motorbike brakes, skids, aqua-glid - SLAMS into Saroo - who sits up - YOW! - head bleeding, watermelon gloop all around him, as the motorcyclist kick starts his bike, and drives off.
Saroo touches the blood - - blood in the puddle where he sits, blood on his hand -

Saroo runs home through the rain, his shirt bunched to hi head, blood and rain streaming down his tiny torso -  83 - he runs into the UNDERPASS - we recognize this as one o the “Memory Maps” - and into BLACK -
Kamla tends to Saroo’s gash. Saroo’s crying. Shekila’s wailing. Kamla wipes the wound with a cloth. Guddu enters, drenched too. It’s still pouring outside.

Where were you? You were meant to be looking after him! Guddu knows he messed up. He looks upset, ashamed. Saroo Shekila cry and cry. But now Kamla draws Saroo closer, and ever so gently she kisses his forehead better. His crying begins to subside.

But now, it’s not Kamla who kisses it better. It’s Lucy - gentle, loving - kissing that old scar on Saroo’s forehea They've just made love - all those endorphins and oxytoci flooding their bodies - on the mattress on the floor. There’s an edge to it all: Saroo’s life still looks bache transient and obsessively preoccupied; Lucy is conflicted knowing she shouldn’t really have gone down this path. But god it’s nice, after sex: even with the floating sadn
That village might not even exist any more. Entire worlds change in twenty-five years. I worry that ... - but she lets it trail off, and hang.
That what? Long, sad pause.

That you’re chasing ghosts. She stands, pulls on her shirt. Smiles that brittle, pain loving smile at him. And his own heart is broken, because he knows he can’t do anything but keep on with that search. She opens the door, walks out.  84

It could be later the same day. It could be another day. has blended into something amorphous. Saroo lies on his lonely mattress. All is still; even the sea is calm. Then past silently weaves into his consciousness, all these vignettes and flashbacks united in their stillness, as hi eyes flicker closed:
ON KAMLA - unmoving, sensing Saroo;
ON little AMITA, lying in bed, staring.
ON CAFE GUY - his kind stare through the cafe window (as Saroo sits on that traffic island, fantasizing non-existe food on his rusty bent spoon -

ON WIRY BOY - just moments before he decides to offer the cardboard, dignity and generosity - then: INT. BEDROOM, NOOR’S ROOFTOP HOME, MORNING (FLASHBACK) ON RAMA - his slow-moving hand along Saroo’s leg ...
You’re a good boy. Are you a good boy? (O/S AUDIO) Whimpering - a scuffle - shouts. A confusing auditory nightmare. Beatings. Cries of anguish. Rape. Lil
ON HAUNTED BOY, swaying back and forth, rubbing his hair forehead, a pressure cooker about to explode. He bangs hi head against the wall, over and over.

The SOUND of Haunted Boy banging his head carries over in screaming and sudden pandemonium, as the CHILD-SNATCHERS arrive and the URCHINS scream and scatter and WIRY BOY is violently grabbed and wrenched away, screaming -
Saroo’s eyes, still flickering. Guddu sits in the dark - dusk or dark now - watching over Saroo. Keeping his dista Giving Saroo space. He knows the memories are the search.  85
A knock at the door. Saroo wakes and goes to the window. Looks down.
John, looking up. He has a “care package” from Sue. He pu it by the door. He waits. Nothing.

It’s the One Day International tomorrow. Come over if you like. We'll get some beer and pizzas. Nothing from inside the house. INSIDE: Saroo just stands there, pressed against the wall Frozen. Conflicted.
I meant to tell you - I fixed the tiller. Why don’t we take her out, head up the coast? Maybe see if we can round up Mantosh. Pause. John, listening.
Saroo, your mum’s not - Whatever he was about to say ("Your mum’s not doing so well”), he stops it. Looks down at the care package.
Your mum’s made a nice cake for you. Put a few other goodies in here too. (beat) I think she’d love a visit. He stands there, hoping against hope that Saroo will sudd appear.
Right. Take care, son. He turns to walk away.
Saroo sits on the beach, a starry night. Watching the wat the ghost-waves marking time like a pulse ...

A night light in the kitchen illuminates Sue, standing at sink. Her arms hanging limp. Exhausted. Mute.  86 Five-year-old Saroo steps beside her. Reaches up, takes h hand. She snaps out of it, looks down on him. It’s all right, s the look on his face. A private communion. The son comforting the mother. Then, if remembering her duty to look after him, Sue pulls Saro close, cradles his head. They stand there, a silent tableau. INT. SUE’S ART STUDIO, BRIERLEY HOME - AFTERNOON Concern registers on Saroo’s face as he enters the little room. Sue sits in the weak sunlight by the window. She lo pale and unwell, in her dressing gown, nursing a cup of t Saroo doesn’t look crash-hot either - months of no sleep exercise have taken their toll. Two lost souls. But she brightens at the sight of Saroo.
(hugging her) I’m sorry. I’m sorry. He sits opposite her. She holds back tears.
John just heard, he’s been out on the boats. Doing the lobster run. They’re due back tomorrow. Saroo looks at her, doesn’t want to admit what this means
So he’1l be flush for cash. And then back on the hard stuff ... Saroo can see in her pain how much she loves Mantosh. She smiles bravely, her pale eyes sparkling.
I’m sorry you couldn’t have your own kids. ON SUE: a misconception, dawning on her.
What are you saying?

I mean, we weren’t blank pages, were we? Like your own would have been. You weren't just adopting us, but our pasts as well. (beat) And I feel like we're killing you.  87 Sue smiles - still holding off the tears.
We could have had children. We chose not to. ON SAROO: shocked by this new information.
Wait. You could have had kids?

Never made that public. Some things need to stay private. Some people would never understand why you’d start a family like ours. We wanted you two in our lives. We chose that. Saroo is moved. Listening intently. SUE (CONT’D) (smiles, remembering) I think it’s one of the reasons I fell in love with your dad. (beat) We both felt the world had more than enough people in it already. Because to have a child - that’s no guarantee that’s going to make things better. But to take a child who's suffering - like you boys were - and to give him a chance in the world. Well, then. Now there’s something. Saroo looks with wonder at his mother. What she’s given u Without her, where would he have ended up?
I bet you never imagined it would be this hard.

It’s not a matter of hard or easy. There was only ever one path. That’s how I believe things happen. (beat) When I was twelve, I had a vision. Some people would call it a breakdown ... Saroo, completely intrigued by his mother opening up like this - in such strange ways.
You know my father was an alcoholic. Out of control. (MORE )

All wrong. I remember I was weeping. Or I'd wept it all out. There were no more tears. I was standing out the back of the house. Looking out across this field. I literally wanted the earth to swallow me. There wasn’t any joy. Life was a nightmare. And I felt this kind of - electric current - electric shock - jolt through me. And there was a little brown- skinned boy across that field. I couldn’t even tell if it was just my eyes playing tricks. And then he was beside me. Just standing there. And I sensed it so strongly. I could feel his warmth.
Really?
Literally. The left side of my body started to heat up.
Did you try to talk to him?
It wasn’t like that. Anyway, I was doubting my sanity. Even as it happened.
It didn't speak?

It stood beside me. And for once in my bleak life, I felt something good. And I knew it was guiding me. And I knew - in my heart - I'd be fine. It was as if, at that moment, I could suddenly believe in the future. Saroo sits there, haunted and entranced by her story.
And now - I don’t know where I’m going. I don’t know what anything means any more. I thought I could hold everything together. By an act of will.
- oh, Mum -  89
But it’s all just splinters. Everything splintering off. Saroo, pained. He shrugs, palms up: I don’t know what to
Way down there, Saroo’s car travels along the wild, lush, remote Tasmanian coast.

head_text.subj: I/E. CAR / NEAR DOVER LOBSTER PORT

text: Saroo winds down towards a wild windswept inlet. Towards Mantosh’s shed... EXT. MANTOSH’S SHED - CONTINUOUS Saroo pulls up, gets out, bangs on doors. Peers in throug the windows.

(calls) Mantosh! Wide: the lonely ghost gums echo his call. INT. SAROO’S CAR - CONTINUOUS He gets back in the car, to wait it out... the trees, the isolation... the quiet... relief almost... He winds his seat back. Stillness.
That one is Makara, the sea monster. You see his long tail?
Ammi - if he’s a sea monster, can he fly?
Looking DOWN on Kamla, Guddu, Kallu and Saroo (Shekila wrapped in swaddling, sound asleep), all lying on their b on the flat roof, looking up at the stars.
I don’t know. It’s as deep as the ocean up there. Pause. They’re all staring straight up, in wonder.
(gesturing) See the bright one, and the line like that? That’s Simha. The lion.  90
Will he eat us?

He might. When he gets hungry enough. ON Saroo: gazing up. Sheer wonder. Thinking about Simha. REVERSE - their POV. The incomparable spread of stars. INT. SAROO’S CAR - DUSK Saroo, looking up at the ceiling of his car. A single tear rolls from his eye. Gentle SOUNDS on the ro spitting of rain. BANG on the window - a wet and bedraggled MANTOSH, has ju pulled up in his UTE, waders over his arm, smoking a join

Brother from another mother. Your hair looks as bad as mine. Saroo, sits up, gets out. Mantosh offers Saroo the joint. Saroo shakes his head No. Mantosh takes a big toke. Flicks the joint away. INT. MANTOSH’S SHED - CONTINUOUS Inside, it’s barely habitable. A grimy sink. A rickety ta A single bed with grey blankets that look damp. Mantosh pours cheap whisky into two grubby glasses. He tu the RADIO on low. They sit, clink glasses, take a sip. Mantosh’s cheery fac fails to hide his desolation and desperation. He holds his hand out, horizontal.
I’m off the speed, mate. Perhaps his hand trembles, just a little; Saroo notices.
That’s good. ‘Cos Mum’s not well.
(wary) Oh yeah? What is it?
Stress. She thinks she’s gonna lose you - (MORE)
(quick adjustment: ) - us. She’s worried about us. It hangs there. Big thing for Saroo to say. Mantosh, taki it in. His heart shifts, a notch. His big brother just sp of them as an ‘us’.
That’s no good.
Nah.
I should get out to see her.

Yeah. Long pause. SAROO (CONT’D) I’m sorry for what I said at dinner. Mantosh shrugs, remembering. A silent, painful It’s nothi SAROO (CONT’D) You been all right? Just the act - the intention - of Saroo trying to connect breaks something open in Little Brother. Mantosh heaves a single sudden dry sob - then stops it. All the world’s pa in those shoulders.

We were the untouchables. You know that, don’t you? You know how much our lives were worth. Nothing. Zero. (remembering: such pain) They had no problem touching me. He looks up at Saroo as if coming out of a trance.
You were one of the lucky ones. I’m not having a go at you. I’m genuinely happy for you.
What do you mean, “luck”? - Mate, I think about my mother in India every day, knowing I’1l never see her again. Same as you.  92

(smiling, but an edge) Not the same. I had bad luck being born. You got LOST! That’s all that happened, bro. And before anything bad even happened, you got whisked off to Australia. Do you know how long I was in Liluah for? Fourteen months. Silence.
Not untouchable in there. Silence. Saroo, staring at Mantosh. The “lucky ones”. He knows he’s got a point: at Liluah, Saroo escaped the bogeyman.

What happened to you was bad. It was just bad. But this is not how you deal with it, Mantosh. You think I’m lucky; I think I made my own luck. I don’t know which one’s true. I didn’t have choices. When that train took off, I didn’t have a choice. You've got to keep going. Sometimes that’s all it is. Mantosh just looks at him. They both seem exhausted. SAROO (CONT’D) You've suffered enough.
I’m persevering, bro. Trust me.

I’ve already lost a brother. I don’t want to lose you too. (beat) I need you, bro. We gotta keep this family together. You and me. A light coming back into Mantosh’s eyes. Just hearing thi But then, too, the irony:

We do things differently, you and me. You try to remember. I try to forget. Saroo is moved by his insight. They sit in silence in thi new, fragile camaraderie - the radio still playing low, B Mantosh stands at a song he likes. Turns up the volume. K Minogue’s I Can’t Get You Out Of My Head.  93 He takes a large swig of whiskey. A big smile spreads. He starts to dance to the music. His ridiculousness is infectious, and Saroo smiles too.
C’mon, dance with your brother! Mantosh turns the volume up louder.

(over the racket) c'mon! Saroo reluctantly gets up. And dances. Two goofy brothers And then: they begin to lose themselves. The scene becomes loud, frenetic, crazy. They can’t belie they’re doing this. They’re laughing like mad.

(shouting in Saroo’s ear) I love you, Saroo. I’m gonna get better. Saroo grins, Okay, then. Good. Mantosh takes a big swig straight from the bottle. Passes it to Saroo, who does the same. Grinning. And now, they really do lose themselves. The dance is completely mad. And glorious. INT. MANTOSH’S SHED - DAWN DAWN. Saroo, wrapped in a blanket. Staring at his sleepin brother. The scars on Mantosh’s hands. The tobacco-staine fingers. The fragility. CLOSE: gently, carefully, Saroo places the old Ganesh medallion in the palm of Mantosh’s hand. He closes Mantosh’s fist around the medallion. EXT. PEBBLY BEACH NEAR MANTOSH’S SHED - DAWN Saroo steps outside into the freezing morning. No one abo Not a sound. Not a bird. Just the WILD WIND and the small gnarly steel-grey WAVES hitting the shore.

Saroo, a tiny figure, walks down to the water’s edge.  94 He strips off - and starts to walk into the water... stop as the pain of the cold kicks in... the endless horizon beyond. He looks back at the shed - Mantosh will not survive with him. He spots Guddu, looking vulnerable, worried, is he losing Saroo?... His locked stare with Guddu. A deep breath from Saroo - - Guddu looks alarmed, as if he wants to stop Saroo - - Saroo DIVES. UNDERWATER - fluid, peaceful, muffled. Saroo’s wild hair flowing. He comes up - roaring - oh, the shock! - his wild wet man
Roaring in pain. Grief. Anger. Knowing he can’t go on. Roaring his past away. BIG emotional moment, then in its wake... Guddu is gone.

Saroo steps up to the wall. All its madness in front of h He reaches for a flag pin. Pulls it out. What’s he doing? He stabs it back into the map - to a totally different pa of India. Way outside the search radius. Then with both hands, he starts pulling out flag pins, stabbing them anywhere. Jumbling them up. Pins everywhere There are pins now all over the place. Pakistan. The Himalayas. He’s just deliberately ruined a year or two of painstakin work. Making certain it’s over, and there’s no turning ba Casually, he SWIPES at a section of printouts spreading o from the main map, scotch-taped together. In a domino eff other printouts tear away. More flag pins go flying. A me He leans his head against the wall. Saroo slumps down on the couch. End of the road. He has t move on too. Over on the Wall: that mess he’s just made.  95 The laptop sits open on the couch. He leans across, place his finger on the trackpad, follows a train line - - then starts to flick the track pad, faster. So that bef the station has time to reach full resolution - - he flicks again, carelessly, without method. And suddenly - it’s a kind of goodbye - he veers off the line completely - out over land - and more land - - doing on the SCREEN what he just did on the WALL - - random shifts, here, there, left, right. Jerky. EVERYTH starts cascading in his psyche, as his memories make thei final fight for life. So we see MAD SNIPPETS and FLASHES: GUDDU - COAL THEFT - DAM - JOY - UNDERPASS - STREETS —

- and on and on it goes - interwoven with the Google Eart search on screen, as Saroo carelessly continues flicking cursor, saying goodbye to the search as his past and his memories disintegrate into fragments - He stops. Exhausted. His face perfectly blank. Equally randomly now, he tap-tap-taps on that “Zoom Out” minus si He ZOOMS OUT, higher. Higher. We’re now staring down on a good chunk of India. Scrolling, Saroo flicks quite a distance left. Still just random moves. We are now way outside the search perimeter Nothing matters. Flick, flick. Who cares? And then: something stops him. He tilts his head - ON THE SCREEN: an expanse of ochre fields. He pulls the laptop onto his thighs. Something about that COLOR. Still as the Sphinx, he stares at the screen.

- matching the Google Earth, but real: we’re hovering abo real ochre landscape. STILL. We can hear nature - the tickling of the grass, the whole earth vibrating. (NOTE: this shot should also recognizably MATCH the lands of the 4000-feet-above-India shot, those parched ochre fi from the opening AERIALS...] -
Saroo shivers. The sound of the gentle wind over him. Jus staring at that screen.  96

CLOSE on little Saroo’s hand, scavenging through the tras at that moment the YELLOW BUTTERFLY lands on it. As he carefully stands, and spreads his arms: PANORAMIC WIDE of an ochre landscape. Full of yellow butterflies. The YELLOW is fluttering, fluttering, and starts FILLING FRAME. AUDIO: very faintly a haunting refrain rises: the lullaby little Amita sang that long-ago night in Liluah.

The lullaby carries over to the present - we’re back with Saroo - more ALERT - scrolling on the Google screen - We scroll over fields. Villages. Then a railway line. He does what he’s always done: trace the tracks to find t next station. - A FLASH: POV FROM MOVING TRAIN (from when he was trappe of those WIDE OCHRE FIELDS - He keeps scrolling, scrolling. And soon enough: the train line enters a mid-sized TOWN. We're over the centre of the town. He zooms in closer. The Google Earth blue railway station symbol, hovering. The rail lines. The platform. Closer in. Closer. And then, on Saroo: Huh. What’s that? ON GOOGLE EARTH SCREEN: it’s blurry. But it looks a littl like a water tower. Saroo blinks, looking at it. Zooming in. His head tilts: - this water tower, getting a little clearer as he zooms. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 1 - WATER TOWER (NIGHT) Little Saroo alone on the deserted platform. Where’s Gudd Saroo shivers, holding himself. He looks up. At the tower

Saroo, sitting up straight. Looking as spooked as that ch  97 ON SCREEN: it’s a WATER TOWER. It’s certainly similar. Saroo leans in closer to the screen. His finger touches t platform. And the water tower. Working out the angles. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 1 - WATER TOWER (NIGHT) We PUSH IN on little Saroo, standing frightened on that haunted platform, looking up at the water tower off-scree REVERSE: we PUSH IN on the water tower.
ON SCREEN: zooming, closer, closer. The satellite resolut becoming clearer. That’s a tower. That’s the water tower. The pixels coarsen and blur as the zoom reaches its limit
(a breath) It can’t be - Saroo actually cups his hands over his mouth. His back is ramrod straight. His nerves on fire - - and suddenly, frantically, he scrolls, scrolls, scrolls
High in the air, we RUSH across the Indian landscape -

- ON GOOGLE EARTH SCREEN: as he scrolls, the pointer race across the landscape in jerks: across ochre fields, acros rivers, roads ... sometimes the train line is on screen a sometimes not - because Saroo’s not following the track n he knows where he’s going - - he’s going HERE: - it’s a DAM. Holy shit. It’s a dam. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 2 - DAM (DAY) Guddu’s POV: we’re spinning in a circle, holding onto Sar with outstretched arms as he too shrieks with laughter. WIDE of same: Guddu twirls Saroo around in the shallow wa by the dam, tiny Saroo’s feet barely skimming the surface Guddu lets go, Saroo flies into the water. He jumps up, laughing. Drenched in golden sunlight.  98

Saroo’s hands are shaking. Fingers on the track pad, urge This cannot be happening. He zooms in closer. ON Google Earth screen, more details: clay shore, the LONG DAM WALL. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 2 - DAM (DAY) - a beautiful, sun-drenched moment: five-year-old Saroo sprinting homewards, the dam receding behind him (with it LONG DAM WALL). Elation and urgency mixed together.
Saroo keeps scrolling, paying 1000% attention. ON SCREEN: he stops on the town. Saroo, scrolling. Eyes attentive to every detail. ON SCREEN: the name hovering above the town is “Khandwa”.
(it doesn’t ring a bell) Khandwa?... But his fingers trace across the screen. There’s the STAT
Little Saroo continues running home, past Khandwa Station
Saroo, scrolling along - - ON GOOGLE EARTH SCREEN: the UNDERPASS - SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 3 - UNDERPASS (DAY) Little Saroo continues running home - into the underpass
- and pops out the other side -
Saroo, scrolling frantically. Nose inches from the screen ON GOOGLE EARTH SCREEN: we scroll OVER the underpass - ou the other side - following roads -
- left, right, right - the roads getting narrower ...  99 And now, at last: a NAME floats above this part of town.
ON Saroo: what?? WHAT                        ! ON SCREEN: there it is. Floating. “Ganesh Talai”.

Ganesh Talai. Ganesh Talay. Ganestlay. He gasps. Then an involuntary LAUGH comes from deep in hi belly. A feeling that this can’t be happening. And now he picks up speed, and scrolls, ever faster - - ON SCREEN: the streets, narrower and narrower —
Little Saroo, sprinting, lungs bursting, joyful, homeward

- Saroo, glued to the screen. Scrolling. Left, right. The streets getting narrower. ON SCREEN: a street so narrow it could only be an alleywa SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 4 - ALLEYWAY TO HOME (DAY We FOLLOW over little Saroo’s shoulder as he rounds the f corner to the narrow alley to home: past the house with t lurid aqua walls, past the overflowing bougainvillea -

ON SCREEN: We stop. Above a nondescript CLUSTER OF SHACKS We ZOOM, closer, closer. Towards a single specific BUILDI Closer. Until the pixels coarsen, and the roof is a blur. Saroo, breathing hard. Staring so intently at the screen. That blurry, pixellated roof fills the entire screen. On Saroo, brimming with emotion.
(very softly) Ammi ... - that Hindi word, rising up from the deep.
Saroo knocks. Lucy comes to the door. They stare at each other. She looks frightened - what’s happened...

I found home... Her face - doubt, belief, joy for him. Did you just say w I think you said? Saroo’s eyes, wide in amazement. That’s a Yes. Lucy wraps her arms around Saroo. They embrace tightly - what does this mean for them? Held in that embrace - rocking gently together - Saroo breathes.
Saroo holds the door open as Sue walks into the room. John, just arrived in his work clothes, stands there, pro as punch - watching his wife.

You need to look at this - Sue enters slowly, mesmerized by something off-screen. Emotions palpably rippling across her face. REVERSE: we follow her as she walks up to the map - it’s still in disarray from Saroo’s flag pin destruction, but can see how amazing and methodical it was. Sue studies it. The grandeur, the scope, the epic madness even in its fractured state. Its magnificence. ON Saroo: watching her, anticipating her response.
This is where you've been? He nods.
I didn’t want you to feel I was ungrateful... Sue takes it all in, astonished.
Saroo. She embraces him, overcome with emotion.  101
I really hope she’s there. She needs to see how beautiful you are. John joins in the embrace.

Saroo in his window seat on the plane. Peering out, down the dark earth. Most everyone else is asleep, and the lig are dimmed. But Saroo’s awake, and deep in thought. And just like that five-year-old - twenty-five years ago, heading off to the unknown - he pulls the shade down, up. only once.

We’re back in our mythic, prehistoric, dust-shrouded landscape. The washed-out whiteness. The white dust. And again, Saroo running across the sun-baked rubble, whi with dust himself. Everything so heightened and surreal.

Ammi! Ammi! He’s carrying something close to his chest, like a bright orange heart. He’s beaming, proud. SAROO (CONT’D) Ammi! And there in the distance, Kamla turns again. Shading her eyes against the sun. Covered in the white quarry dust. SAROO (CONT’D) Look what I’ve got! He reveals his offering: in the middle of all that white perfect, bulbous MANGO. Glowing in its perfect orangeness She reaches out her hand. Touches his face in thanks. Wha unimaginable treat.

Saroo and Kamla sit on the rocky ground, devouring the ma The juice streaks their dust-caked faces. Sucking at the flesh, the nectar. A playful delight coursing through the SAROO (CONT’D) I threw a rock. I knocked it out of the tree!  102
(grinning, nodding) Good boy.

text: Saroo in the back seat of the taxi. Peering intently out window at the landscape rolling by. The fields. The small towns.

We FOLLOW CLOSE behind Saroo as he enters his hotel room throws the backpack on the bed. Saroo at the window. Looking down on the bus terminal and further away - train station from this third floor room. POV: all the mad activity down there in the streets.
Saroo lies fully clothed, spread on the bed. Shoes still Arms spread. Staring up at the ceiling. He’s wide, wide awake. The ceiling fan turning. No way he getting twelve hours’ sleep.
All right. He leaps up.
Saroo walks along the busy street. Hard to read his face. Past the busy station. And suddenly now in front of him: UNDERPASS. He strides ahead. His legs carrying him forwar now.
Saroo strides along the road. Purposeful.

Saroo knows exactly where he’s going. Automatic pilot thr those never-forgotten streets. Turning left. Turning righ Now he RUNS - as he did through these streets as a child. EXT. ALLEYWAY TO SAROO’S CHILDHOOD HOME - MINUTES LATER Saroo turns into a narrow alley. Heart positively poundin He rounds the next bend and -  103 - stops dead. From BEHIND, his view down the ALLEY, past that house wit those (now faded) lurid aqua walls, past the overflowing bougainvillea: we recognise that long-ago childhood home. REVERSE of this: looking at Saroo. Only it’s 5-YEAR-OLD-S who’s standing there now. Still as a statue. Awed. Little Saroo starts moving forwards, towards home. We tra backwards with him. He’s not scared, just calm, amazed. H been waiting for this moment for a long, long time. He arrives at the door - HARD CUT to side angle: now it’s ADULT Saroo, peering in through the rotted slats of the door - And ... it’s abandoned in there. His POV: in there, in the gloom, there’s NOTHING. That di floored shack, the rubble of a former life. He steps back. So that’s it. Shit. Stands there, at a los
(in Hindi) Can I help you? Saroo turns. It’s a WOMAN, 21, with a BABY in her arms.

Hi! Um - I used to live here. (off her blank look) You don’t speak - ? (pointing at the shack) I used to live here. He unfolds a sheet of paper. ON THE SHEET: it’s an enlarged photocopy of that photo ta at the police station when he was five. SAROO (CONT’D) That’s me. I used to live here. The woman nods politely. But can’t understand a word he s A middle-aged MAN pokes his head out from a doorway.
Hello?
Hello. You speak English?
Yes. A little.  104
Have you lived here long?
Some time.
(pointing at photo) I’m Saroo. This is me. (pointing at empty house) I'm looking for, um. Kamla, Guddu, Kallu, Shekila. The man looks from Saroo to the house. To Saroo.
Here? You lived here?
Here. Yes. The man takes a long look at Saroo. Squinting.

Wait here. And he simply turns, and walks away. Saroo: every nerve ending is alive. We CIRCLE him. Everyt else a background BLUR - chatter in Hindi, PEOPLE popping of doorways. And Saroo staring down the alley to where that man just disappeared around a corner. Where has he gone? Saroo starts walking, as in a dream, toward the corner. The people trailing him. But we’re CLOSE with Saroo. Momentarily, the man reappears around the corner. ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN (CONT’D) Come.
Come where?

(he’s already moving) Come. They walk. Saroo in his trance. Rounding the corner - Saroo, the man, the curious HANGERS And fifty metres ahead, there are THREE WOMEN standing th stunned, uncertain. Two of them flanking the ONE IN THE MIDDLE, lightly holding her by the elbows.  105 Behind them, their own entourage of curious HANGERS-ON. On Saroo: brain about to explode. This can’t be real. Can As Saroo and entourage move towards the three women, the three women and entourage begin to move towards him. PUSHING IN towards the women: to that one, CENTRE OF FRAM Kamla. A quarter of a century older. Still as beautiful. REVERSE - PUSHING IN towards Saroo, as he walks towards u On Kamla: with immense confusion and reservation, staring at this giant man, this total stranger. - and as she gets closer, looking into his eyes -
Ammi - - and she knows it’s him.
Sheru! They embrace each other, tightly.

(close, soft) I’m sorry. I’m sorry. They hold the embrace. Then Kamla starts running her hands over Saroo’s face. SAROO (CONT’D) It’s me - (showing her the photo) Look - The instant Kamla looks at the photo, it ALL comes back, she weeps. Hugging Saroo, wailing, touching his face. The commotion growing. PEOPLE appearing. Explanations fly
The little crowd has grown further. Everyone talking at o Kamla can’t stop hugging Saroo, touching him, squeezing h
Are you sure it’s him?
(stabbing the photo) It’s him. I know it’s him. My son has come back.  106 She reaches up, parts the hair on his forehead. Sure enou the scar.
The watermelons!
(in Hindi) Watermelons.
The watermelons!
(in Hindi, imitating) Tarabuja! [Watermelon] (beat) And Guddu? Where is Guddu?
(heartbroken) Guddu. Guddu. Saroo, not wanting to believe what he thinks she’s saying

Guddu is no more. (beat; clarifies) He is with God. Amidst all this surreal joy, a knife in the heart. Saroo looks at the man - numb and uncomprehending. He looks to Kamla: is it true? Surely it’s not true. In her eyes: it’s true. It’s true. Such sorrow. They embrace. She weeps. AUDIO muffles - they’re in some private space that sound can’t penetrate. They gaze into other’s eyes. Pain, love, joy - Then: a COMMOTION. The crowd parts for ADULT SHEKILA (27)
(she’s nearly hysterical) Shekila! It’s him! (to Saroo) This is Shekila! This is your sister! Saroo, amazed.

Shekila? Kamla nods yes; a howl of joy from Saroo -  107 SAROO (CONT’D) Shekila! He pulls her into the embrace. The onlookers crowding and touching him, as if he’s not r Saroo and his mother and sister, locked in the embrace.

That last night together, twenty-five years ago: little Saroo, King of the World, perched on the handlebars as Gu pedals for all he’s worth through the streets of Khandwa. They're gliding. Banking. Soaring. The world is rushing b
Go, Guddu! It’s as if they’re being cheered through the very streets SMALL FADE.

Saroo - a profoundly changed man - at the window, looking over Khandwa and the train station. The street stalls, the lights, the endless traffic. SUE’S PHONE MESSAGE (V.O.) Hello. You've reached Sue Brierley. I can’t get to the phone right now, please leave a message.
Hi Mum. I know you’1l be sound asleep. (MORE ...)

The warm late sun floods the air as we come upon adult Sa walking along the water’s edge by the dam, where a new generation of KIDS are splashing and playing - just as Sa used to do, twenty-five years ago. The dam wall over there. Out in the water: two BOYS frolicking, shrieking. Saroo, watching them.

.+. I just want to say that I’m safe. I’m safe, and all questions have been answered. There are no more dead ends. (MORE ...)  108 INT. JOHN AND SUE’S BEDROOM - EARLY MORNING Sue, sitting up in bed - holding her mobile, listening to message on speakerphone, John beside her listening too - tears well in their eyes.

My mother thanks you both for raising me. She understands you’re my family. She’s happy just knowing I’m alive. (long beat) I found Ammi. But that doesn’t change us. I love you, Mum. So much. And you, Dad. And Mantosh. We're a family.
Saroo stands there by the dam. Taking it all in. He turns. Up ahead: that ridge where the railway track ru Saroo starts walking up the embankment to the track.

Saroo is walking TOWARDS US along the tracks. Stepping on every second sleeper. The dam over there, B/G. REVERSE: MATCH SHOT so it feels like a normal reverse, BU ON THE REVERSE: it’s twelve-year-old Guddu and five-year- Saroo, walking AWAY FROM US down that long stretch of tra Guddu’s arm draped over Saroo’s shoulder. Saroo dragging stick behind him, clack-clack-clack along the sleepers. They're literally walking off into the sunset. And we

- We’re RISING UP into the air - we’re leaving them now - we're going HIGH - HIGHER - we’re SOARING UP AND AWAY - We're very HIGH - they’re TINY SPECKS - we’re FADING TO BLACK. In the blackness, SUPERS come up, one after the other: Saroo Brierley made it back to Ganesh Talai on February 1 2012. He’d been lost for over 25 years.  109 He learned that 25 years earlier, on the same night he stepped up into that carriage, his brother Guddu died - h by a train not far from the platform. Saroo’s mother, Kamla, had never given up hope of Saroo’s return, and had never moved away. She said she was “surprised with thunder” that her boy ha come back, and that the happiness in her heart was “as de as the ocean.” Saroo learned that all those years ago, as a five-year-ol he had been mispronouncing his own name. He was “Sheru” - - “LION”
